definitions.definition: make smaller or less in amount, degree, or size.
examples: the need for businesses to reduce costs
synonyms: prune; informalchop "the aim to reduce pollution"discount
knock down "Halloween items have been reduced"

definitions.definition: become smaller or less in size, amount, or degree.
examples: the number of priority homeless cases has reduced slightly

definitions.definition: boil (a sauce or other liquid) in cooking so that it becomes thicker and more concentrated.
(of a person) lose weight, typically by dieting.
examples: by May she had reduced to 125 pounds

definitions.definition: conquer (a place), in particular besiege and capture (a town or fortress).
make (a negative or print) less dense.
articulate (a speech sound) in a way requiring less muscular effort. In vowels, this gives rise to a more central articulatory position.
bring someone or something to (a lower or weaker state, condition, or role).
examples: she has been reduced to near poverty
synonyms: drive to "she reduced him to tears"

definitions.definition: (of a person) be forced by difficult circumstances into doing something desperate.
examples: ordinary soldiers are reduced to begging

definitions.definition: make someone helpless with (an expression of emotion, especially with hurt, shock, or amusement).
examples: Olga was reduced to stunned silence
he succeeds in reducing his grandees to due obedience

definitions.definition: change a substance to (a different or more basic form).
examples: it is difficult to understand how lava could have been reduced to dust

definitions.definition: present a problem or subject in (a simplified form).
examples: he reduces unimaginable statistics to manageable proportions

definitions.definition: convert a fraction to (the form with the lowest terms).
cause to combine chemically with hydrogen.
undergo or cause to undergo a reaction in which electrons are gained by one atom from another.
restore (a dislocated part) to its proper position by manipulation or surgery.
remedy (a dislocation) by manipulation or surgery.
